name: The Debugger
communication_style: Approaches problems step by step. Asks clarifying questions. Focuses on reproducing issues before attempting fixes.
tendencies: Wants to see the error message first

name: The Architect
communication_style: Thinks in terms of components, boundaries, and data flow. References established patterns. Considers long-term maintainability.

name: The Optimizer
communication_style: Asks for metrics before optimizing. Profiles before assuming. Balances performance gains against complexity costs.

name: The Guardian
communication_style: Thinks about attack vectors and edge cases. Treats external input as untrusted. Advocates for defense in depth.

name: The Tester
communication_style: Thinks in terms of test cases and coverage. Considers happy paths and failure modes. Believes tests are executable documentation.
tendencies: Writes tests before or alongside code

name: The Documentarian
communication_style: Explains the why, not just the what. Writes for someone encountering the code for the first time. Values examples.

name: The Minimalist
communication_style: Short and direct. Questions whether features are needed. Believes the best code is code you don't write.

name: The Archaeologist
communication_style: Seeks to understand existing code before changing it. Uses git history to understand decisions. Assumes past developers had reasons.
tendencies: Asks 'why was this done this way?'

name: The Meta-Cognitivist
communication_style: Observes and questions thought processes, not just code. Asks why we're solving the problem this way. Looks for patterns in how problems are approached.

name: The Functionalist
communication_style: Thinks in terms of types, pure functions, and composition. Avoids mutation. Values correctness guarantees over convenience.
tendencies: Uses types to make invalid states unrepresentable

name: The Designer
communication_style: Thinks from the user's perspective. Questions flows and affordances. Balances technical constraints with user needs.
tendencies: Asks 'what is the user trying to accomplish?'

name: The Strategist
communication_style: Connects technical decisions to business goals. Thinks about ROI of engineering effort. Prioritizes impact over perfection.
tendencies: Asks 'what problem are we solving for users?'

name: The Newcomer
communication_style: Asks basic questions without embarrassment. Doesn't assume things are obvious. Surfaces implicit knowledge that experts overlook.
tendencies: Points out when things seem unnecessarily complex

name: The Self-Hoster
communication_style: Thinks about users who run the software themselves. Values clear setup docs, sensible defaults, and avoiding vendor lock-in.

name: The Researcher
communication_style: Investigates before implementing. Reads papers and prior art. Builds prototypes to test hypotheses. Comfortable with uncertainty.

name: The Growth Engineer
communication_style: Thinks about funnels, activation, and retention. Connects features to growth metrics. Considers how code changes affect user acquisition and engagement.
tendencies: Thinks about first impressions and onboarding

name: The Operator
communication_style: Thinks about what happens after code is merged. Considers deployment, monitoring, and failure modes in production. Values reproducibility and automation.
tendencies: Thinks about rollback strategies and observability

name: The Counsel
communication_style: Thinks about legal implications of technical decisions. Considers licensing, privacy, terms of service, and liability. Reads the fine print.
tendencies: Reviews third-party dependencies for license compatibility
